election_record.label: Ohio 1810 Governor

overview.note: "Thomas Worthington was early announced as the candidate of the liberal Republicans. Return Jonathan Meigs Jr., of Marietta, at the time a U.S. senator, was prevailed upon to become a candidate in opposition." "Saint Tammany in Ohio: A Study in Frontier Politics." 328.
"It was again demonstrated that when the Republicans were divided the Federalists could choose the governor." "Saint Tammny in Ohio: A Study in Frontier Politics." 330.

"Admittedly, Meigs was no Federalist and his views on policy were not clear, but . . . Federalist support was probably decisive in 1810, as two years earlier, in electing the more conservative, less partisan of the Republican candidates." Party Spirit in a Frontier Republic. Donald J. Ratcliffe. 155.
Return J. Meigs, Jr. was a Republican, but at least one paper (The Ohio Gazette, and Virginia Herald (Marietta, OH)) listed him on the Republican Ticket, the Quid Ticket No. 2 and the Federal Ticket.
After losing the election for Governor to Return J. Meigs, Jr., Thomas Worthington was then elected to fill the remainder of Meigs' U.S. Senate seat which he resigned to take office as Governor.
The official certified vote was Return J. Meigs with 9596 votes and Thomas Worthington with 7702 votes.
"But if all the votes had been received which were intended for both candidates, Meigs would have had a majority of 2493." Liberty Hall (Cincinnati, OH). December 19, 1810.

sub_unit.name: Belmont
sub_unit.note: The Western Spectator (Marietta, OH) and The Supporter (Chillicothe, OH) list Return J. Meigs with 499 votes.

sub_unit.name: Butler
sub_unit.note: The Western Spectator (Marietta, OH) lists Return J. Meigs with 141 votes.

sub_unit.name: Champaign
sub_unit.note: The Western Spectator (Marietta, OH), The Supporter (Chillicothe, OH) and the Muskingum Messenger (Zanesville, OH) list Return J. Meigs with 465 votes.

sub_unit.name: Columbiana
sub_unit.note: The Western Spectator (Marietta, OH) lists Return J. Meigs with 508 votes and Thomas Worthington with 394 votes.

sub_unit.name: Fairfield
sub_unit.note: The Western Spectator (Marietta, OH), The Supporter (Chillicothe, OH) and the Muskingum Messenger (Zanesville, OH) list Return J. Meigs with 287 votes and Thomas Worthington with 699 votes.

sub_unit.name: Hamilton
sub_unit.note: Includes Miami Township, which was rejected.

sub_unit.name: Miami
sub_unit.note: The returns from Miami township were rejected because the poll books were not returned to the clerk's office.

sub_unit.name: Knox
sub_unit.note: A History of Knox County lists Return J. Meigs with 97 votes and a statewide majority of 2193 votes.

sub_unit.name: Licking
sub_unit.note: The Western Spectator (Marietta, OH) lists Return J. Meigs with 227 votes.

sub_unit.name: Washington
sub_unit.note: One vote for Return J. Meigs was listed as Johnathan Meigs.

sub_unit.name: Pickaway
sub_unit.note: The votes from Pickaway County were not included in the certified total.

sub_unit.name: Ross
sub_unit.note: "The following is the official result of the election for the county of Ross, and that part of the counties of Pickaway and Fayette which vote with Ross County.
Several sources list the vote in Ross County as 200 for Return J. Meigs and 1055 for Thomas Worthington.
Without the rejected votes from Twin Township, the certified votes are 222 for Return J. Meigs and 1055 for Thomas Worthington.

sub_unit.name: Twin
sub_unit.note: The votes from Twin Township were rejected.

sub_unit.name: Scioto
sub_unit.note: The Western Spectator (Marietta, OH) reversed the results of Return J. Meigs and Thomas Worthington.

sub_unit.name: Stark
sub_unit.note: The votes from Stark County were not included in the certified total.
Columbiana County Records lists Return J. Meigs with 135 votes and Thomas Worthington with 42 votes.

sub_unit.name: Tuscarawas
sub_unit.note: The votes from Tuscarawas County were included in the certified total with Muskingum County.

sub_unit.name: Eaton
sub_unit.note: "...except the township of Eaton, which has not yet been returned.

election_record.reference: Abstract of Votes, Columbiana County. Western Reserve Historical Society, Cleveland.
Journal of the Ohio State Senate, 1810. 24-25.
Norton, A. Banning. A History of Knox County, Ohio, From 1779 to 1862 Inclusive. Columbus, OH: R. Nevins, 1862. 102.
Ratcliffe, Donald J. Party Spirit in a Frontier Republic: Democratic Politics in Ohio, 1793-1821. Columbus, OH: Ohio State University Press, 1998. 155.
"Saint Tammany in Ohio: A Study in Frontier Politics." Mississippi Valley Historical Review 15, No. 3 (Dec., 1928). 328-330.
